The Dry Hall

// A short term parametric design exercise

A dual function architecture - a reservoir during the rainy seasons, a concert hall during the droughts. The concert hall structure is a physical embodiment of the average amount of precipitation in various parts of LA during this past season.

Year 2014
Client Personal
Role Designer
Mentors Tim Durfee

To create the scaled model of the concert hall, I used the precipitation data from March to October in 2014 (measured by LA Department of Public Works), I maped out the inches over time graph. Taking the graph as a cross section, and spinning it around present time point creates the cylindrical form seen above.

 3D model of the Dry Hall and its cross section generated from precipitation data.

Conclusion

The form expresses the data, at the same time assimilate the look of water ripples speading from a point. The project is intended to be a critical statement of the persistant drought in California in the recent years. Starting from the center of the Concerts Hall where time is present, the farther from the center, the farther back in time we travel. Eventually we confront a wall raised before our eyes, its steep front reminds us of the tremendous volume of water we have since being deprived of.

from Shixie. 2015
